content: @Tim Abbott @Rishi Gupta bringing the conversation of what the hotkey should be for narrowing to starred messages?
/bumping this
We could do *, though I don't really like it
or maybe ctr+shift+*, so that we can access it from the compose box
ctrl+shift+* sounds good to me.
the issue with * is that most people don't have finger memory for the key
ideally it would be another Ctr+[letter]
we could also do Alt+s, even though it's probably a firefox menu selector
It isn't a firefox menu selector; I just tested it, but maybe I didn't test it right? So if someone can just double check.
For me it selects History menu on latest firefox on Ubuntu.
Hmm, well then.
I think that might not be much of a loss. Many Alt+[letter]s are going to be some firefox menu selector in some language, and I don't think they are heavily used hotkeys.
I think we should use the * character for some kind of starring shortcut. Either use * to star messages or use it to searched starred messages. Because it’s the star key.
that's what it was originally, but I found in practice it added a lot of friction, to the point that I didn't actually use the feature.
Shift 8 is the amount of friction we are talking about here?
yeah, the fact that 8 is not in finger memory, at least for me, and I imagine for most people
I guess it’s only easy for me to type * because I was forced to take a typing class. How do people who aren’t like me bold stuff in markdown?
haha. You can bold with ctr+b!
I'm not confident about this being hard for everyone; if other people feel the numbers are similar to letters in terms of ease, * would certainly be natural semantically.
I think we should use * for starring.
And respect web standards like control-b and star star for bolding. And control-s for saving. :grinning:

Here’s a little digression. Starring messages on mobile web requires amazing thumb precision. And being on mobile web is precisely when I want to star messages. To come back to them later with an actual keyboard.
to make sure we're talking about the same thing, ctr+s for starring is already out of the bag. The question here is what to use for "Go to starred messages"
Using our app on mobile mostly just exacerbates how small our click targets are for the normal web app. It is an accessibility issue we should probably think about.

Ideally going to starred messages would be mostly arrow keys and we would have an accessibility strategy for each sidebar. Not just for blind people, but they are an audience for sure. Also for anybody that has mouse issues or just people...
....who are impatient like me
Mouse issues are real.
We should always assume some of our users can’t or don’t want to manipulate a mouse for any number or reasons.

we could also do Alt+s, even though it's probably a firefox menu selector

I think we decided not to use Alt in the shortcuts?
https://chat.zulip.org/#narrow/stream/101-design/subject/shortcut.20for.20create.20stream/near/602503
That was for not using ctrl+alt, right?
I think it was for Anything+ALT.
hm. The first article at least seems to think the issue is specific to ctr+alt?
I also think the articles are pointing towards ctrl + alt just because firefox wouldn't use alt + if it was so inconvenient.

We could also thing about 2-character shortcuts. E.g. we have g opening the gear menu, and one can easily have shortcuts for that context; I could imagine a similar thing having a hotkey for "select global filter" and then a 1-character thing to select the starred narrow.
(Not sure if that's better, just brainstorming here)

I like that idea. Coming up with sensible shortcuts has been quite difficult.
[key] -> shift focus to left sidebar
[key] + a -> all messages
[key] + p -> private messages
[key] + s -> starred messages
[key] + m -> mentions
Interesting, we'd have to change how hotkeys work in general to encapsulate that I think.
(It's kind of like Gmail or GitHub hotkeys where it's like g+a)
@Joshua Pan I don't think we do, if what the first hotkey does is e.g. move focus in the app (see how g works in Zulip).
For the upper left corner we should have a hotkey to focus and then maybe just use arrow keys?
we do need quick(er than that) access to "starred messages"
Yeah, arrow keys are a bit too slow.
On Gmail, it's g + s
is l for "left sidebar" too weird?
Ideally for all of these we'd also have something that worked in the compose box, like alt + l
I guess with too many things like l, r, n, etc we run the risk of accidental activation when you start typing thinking you're in compose and you're not
Yes, but that's sorta a concern with basically any keyboard shortcut, and Gmail seems to work well despite having almost every key be a shortcut.
I'm pretty happy with this, then. l can add an overlay to the upper left or the whole left sidebar, to teach whatever shortcuts we add there.
Another way to handle this is to generalize it to a quick-shortcut menu.
A quick-shortcut menu is a way to teach shortcuts like n and p as well as giving quick shortcuts to things like "Starred messages" and "Mentions".

how would be feel about using g for a quick-shortcut menu? I feel like it is kind of the natural key, given that other products (at least gmail and github) seem to use it.

I'm imagining g would add an overlay for the stuff on whatever page you're on (e.g. an a on All messages, a p for private messages, etc) and then could add additional hints in text at the bottom.
We use it for the gear menu now, but I don't consider that a show stopper.
I think using g for this would be reasonable.
As long as we put settings etc. in there, we can replace the current gear menu use case.
I like g for this. (I think of it as "Go to ..." -- and the Gmail keyboard help strongly hints that, too.)

Gmail seems to work well despite having almost every key be a shortcut.

Note that Gmail doesn't have keyboard shortcuts by default -- you have to go into settings and enable them. I suspect there are a lot of Gmail users who have no idea it offers keyboard shortcuts, and would be confused and have a bad time if all Gmail's shortcuts were enabled for them.
(It's easy to forget this because for probably most of us it's one of the very first things we do in a new Gmail account, and that doesn't happen often)

great. Proposed shortcuts:

all messages: Esc += g+a
private messages: P -> g+p (deprecation warning for P, but don't have to actually deprecate it till 1.11)
starred messages: g+s
mentions: g+m

gear menu: g -> g+g
view drafts: d -> g+d
first draft: D

Other notes:

  • We can keep w, q, /, etc working while in "g" mode
  • Every "g" shortcut could also work with Alt+g, so that it works while in compose

It might be good to have g shortcuts for going to "manage streams" and maybe settings/org settings, though not sure what they should be.
"Manage streams" could be `g+S"?

gear menu: g -> g+g

I'm a bit curious about this one: what's the use case that you imagine people wanting to go to this menu frequently enough to learn a shortcut for it?

Oh hm, I see you're saying there already is one for it. TIL. :slight_smile: (I guess that was mentioned in the thread earlier.)

It feels just a bit out of place in the "g+" list, as it doesn't feel like you're "going to" anywhere.
This topic was mentioned in #design > keyboard shortcut for starred messages
Do you guys find Topic Bridge Bot useful?

This particular case was a little disorienting for me, as it created unreads out of a bunch of pretty old threads (although in this case, that was kind of the point). I want to see how it behaves for awhile longer before I judge it too much

Yeah I think I'm not a huge fan of it in the bot form, but if we were to arrange some mechanism where we had a system message (that say, was automatically marked as read and maybe had a special display format that felt a bit nicer), I could imagine it being nice. I do feel like it's not uncommon for me to want to go an manually add a backlink to a topic I mentioned... though the majority of the time I want to add more commentary -- not just a link.

I guess It would be nice to have an option to make bot messages as non triggering unreads... For example topic bridge bot, is it important to actually see its message as unread?
I guess it would be similar to muting a user...
#26005 adds support for muting bots, merged but not deployed yet.

Muting bots isn't super responsive to the request, in that I think folks might want to be able to see the messages when looking at a topic, which muting would disable, btu not get the unread counts.

If we like this particular bot, the right approach probably involves making a built-in feature that could support special behavior around unreads that we don't want to offer to arbitrary bots. (E.g. it would be a moderation misfeature to allow an arbitrary bot to send arbitrary messages that are only shown to some users).
